text: Nicosia, also known as Lefkosia (; ) is the capital city and largest city of the island country of Cyprus. Nicosia is on the Pedieos (Kanlidere) river in the centre of the island. The city is the seat of government as well as the main business centre for Cyprus. Nicosia is capital of the administrative district (Nicosia District). == Division == Nicosia is the only divided capital city in the world. It has a northern (Turkish- Turkish Cypriots trace their origins to the Ottoman conquest of Cyprus in 1571) section and a southern (Greek- Mycenaean Greeks from mainland Greece began settling in Cyprus after the fall of the Mycenaean civilization 1500 BC ) section. These sections are divided by the "Green Line". It is a demilitarized zone created by the United Nations. Nicosia (southern part ) is the capital of the Republic of Cyprus. Nicosia (northern part) is capital of the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus (TRNC), a self declared state, who won their freedom from Republic of Cyprus by the aid of Turkey. Nicosia has a total population of 310,355.Peltenburg, E. J. (2004). "The Rise of the Cypriot Bronze Age." Antiquity, 78(299), 8–14. doi:10.1017/S0003598X00094761 == Features == Nicosia has many shops, restaurants and entertainment. The city is a trade center. It manufactures textiles, leather, pottery, plastic, and other items. Copper mines are nearby. The University of Cyprus (UCY) is in Nicosia. == Climate == Nicosia has a hot semi-arid climate (BSh in the Köppen climate classification). The highest temperature ever recorded in Nicosia was on 4 September 2020. == History == == Chronological Settlers and Rulers of Cyprus == The island of Cyprus has experienced a complex and layered history of settlement, conquest, and administration. Due to its strategic position in the eastern Mediterranean, Cyprus was settled by various civilizations, each leaving a distinct cultural and political mark on the island. === Prehistoric Period (~10,000–2500 BCE) === \- **Aceramic Neolithic settlers** arrived from the Levant around 10,000–7000 BCE.Peltenburg, E. J. (2004). "The Rise of the Cypriot Bronze Age." Antiquity, 78(299), 8–14. doi:10.1017/S0003598X00094761 \- **Chalcolithic culture** flourished around 3900–2500 BCE, particularly in the western and central parts of the island.Bolger, D. (2013). Gender in Ancient Cyprus: Narratives of Social Change on a Mediterranean Island. Lanham, MD: Lexington Books. === Bronze Age (2500–1050 BCE) === \- The **Early Bronze Age** saw migrations from Anatolia and the Aegean around 2500 BCE. - **Mycenaean Greeks** began settling in Cyprus by around 1400 BCE, increasing their presence after the collapse of Mycenaean civilization ca. 1200 BCE.Karageorghis, V. (2000). The Greeks in the Eastern Mediterranean. Nicosia: Leventis Foundation. === Iron Age and Classical Period (1050–323 BCE) === \- **Phoenician settlers** established colonies in Kition in the 9th century BCE.Moscati, S. (1988). The Phoenicians. New York: Abbeville Press. \- The island came under **Assyrian suzerainty** around 709–669 BCE.Kuhrt, A. (1995). The Ancient Near East: c. 3000–330 BCE. Vol. 2. London: Routledge. \- **Egyptian rule** under the 26th Dynasty followed, ca. 570–525 BCE. - Cyprus was later ruled by the **Achaemenid Persian Empire** from ca. 525 to 333 BCE.Briant, P. (2002). From Cyrus to Alexander: A History of the Persian Empire. Winona Lake: Eisenbrauns. === Hellenistic Period (323–58 BCE) === \- After Alexander the Great's death, **Ptolemaic Egypt** controlled Cyprus from ca. 294 to 58 BCE.Meier, M. (2014). A History of Ancient Greece. Berlin: De Gruyter. === Roman and Byzantine Period (58 BCE–1191 CE) === \- Cyprus became a **Roman province** in 58 BCE.Hill, G. (1949). A History of Cyprus, Volume 1. Cambridge University Press. \- After the Roman Empire split, Cyprus remained under **Byzantine control** from 330 to 1191 CE.Metcalf, D. M. (2009). Byzantine Cyprus: Coins and Archaeology. Nicosia: Cyprus Research Centre. === Medieval Period (1191–1489) === \- In 1191, **Richard the Lionheart of England** captured Cyprus during the Third Crusade.Runciman, S. (1951). A History of the Crusades: Volume II. Cambridge University Press. \- The island was briefly held by the **Knights Templar** (1191–1192) before being sold to **Guy of Lusignan**, leading to the **Lusignan Kingdom of Cyprus** (1192–1489).Edbury, P. W. (1991). The Kingdom of Cyprus and the Crusades, 1191–1374. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. === Venetian Rule (1489–1571) === \- **Venetians** formally annexed Cyprus in 1489 and ruled it until the Ottoman conquest.Arbel, B. (1984). Cyprus, the Franks and Venice: 13th–16th centuries. Aldershot: Variorum. === Ottoman Rule (1571–1878) === \- The **Ottoman Empire** took control in 1571 following a campaign led by Lala Mustafa Pasha.İnalcık, H. (1973). The Ottoman Empire: The Classical Age, 1300–1600. London: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. === British Rule (1878–1960) === \- Under the 1878 Cyprus Convention, **Britain assumed control** of the island, which became a Crown colony in 1925.Holland, R. (1998). Britain and the Revolt in Cyprus, 1954–1959. Oxford University Press. === Republic of Cyprus (1960–Present) === \- Cyprus became an **independent republic** in 1960. - Following intercommunal violence and a Greek-backed coup, **Turkey intervened militarily** in 1974, leading to the island's division. Ker-Lindsay, J. (2011). The Cyprus Problem: What Everyone Needs to Know. Oxford University Press. == References == Nicosia was a city-state known as Ledra or Ledrae in ancient times. The king of Ledra was Onasagoras in 672 BC. The city was rebuilt by Lefkos, son of Ptolemy I around 300 BC. Ledra in Hellenic and Roman times was a small, unimportant town, also known as Lefkothea. It got its first Christian bishop, Trifillios, in 348. The city became the island's capital around the 10th century. It had grown in importance because of threats to the coastal cities Paphos and Salamis. These threats made many people leave the coast of the island and move to Lefkosia in the center of the island. The city became a Venetian possession in 1489. It was captured by the Ottoman Empire in 1571. During this time, the city grew culturally. In the 15th and 16th centuries, many palaces, churches and monasteries were built. About 20,000 people living in the city died because of the Ottoman attack of 1570. Many disasters happened in the city during the 19th century. Cholera hit the city in 1835. Fire destroyed large parts of Nicosia in 1857. The British Empire took control of the island in 1878. Nicosia was the capital of the new British colony. In early 1974, a coup d'état instigated by the Greek junta overthrew the legal government and took control. Shortly afterwards Turkey invaded the island occupying a large part, with excuse that Turkish Cypriot people's safety was threatened. Because of this, Cyprus and the city of Nicosia are divided since. Cyprus with its legal government is part of the European Union.
